title: Steve Centanni
text:
Steven James "Steve" Centanni is an American former <a href="news">news</a> <a href="reporter">reporter</a> for <a href="Fox%20News%20Channel">Fox News Channel</a>.
Journalism career.
Centanni joined FNC in 1996.
During <a href="Operation%20Iraqi%20Freedom">Operation Iraqi Freedom</a>, he served as an embedded journalist with the <a href="Navy%20SEALs">Navy SEALs</a> and provided numerous first reports for the network, including a report that the U.S. had captured two main offshore <a href="petroleum">oil</a> terminals located off <a href="Iraq">Iraq</a>'s southern coast, preventing them from being blown up by Iraqi forces.
Previous to Fox, Centanni had worked for <a href="KRON-TV">KRON-TV</a> in <a href="San%20Francisco%2C%20California">San Francisco, California</a>.
Centanni retired in August 2014.
Education.
Centanni attended the <a href="University%20of%20Colorado%20at%20Boulder">University of Colorado at Boulder</a> and earned a <a href="Bachelor%27s%20degree">Bachelor's degree</a> in broadcasting from <a href="San%20Francisco%20State%20University">San Francisco State University</a>.
Gaza kidnapping.
On August 14, 2006, he was kidnapped by <a href="Palestinian%20Authority">Palestinian</a> gunmen while on assignment in <a href="Gaza%20City">Gaza City</a>, along with <a href="Olaf%20Wiig">Olaf Wiig</a>, a <a href="cameraman">cameraman</a> from <a href="New%20Zealand">New Zealand</a>. A witness saw two vehicles blocking the journalist's transmission truck and a masked man put a gun to their bodyguard's head, forcing him to the ground.
An internal message by Fox News Channel Senior Vice President John Moody confirmed the abduction and instructed employees not to comment on it.
On August 19, Fox News Channel broadcast a video by Centanni's brother pleading for the reporter's immediate release.
On August 23, the <a href="Holy%20Jihad%20Brigades">Holy Jihad Brigades</a> claimed responsibility for the kidnappings of both Centanni and Wiig. They demanded the release of all "<a href="Muslim">Muslim</a> prisoners" by the <a href="United%20States">United States</a> within 72 hours. A <a href="http%3A//www.ramattan.com/uploaded/Kidnaped.rar">video</a> was broadcast by <a href="Al-Jazeera">Al-Jazeera</a>. No armed men were in the video, and the captives appeared to be in good health.
On August 26, the three-day deadline passed uneventfully at 9:00 <a href="GMT">GMT</a>. Hours earlier, <a href="Ismail%20Haniyeh">Ismail Haniyeh</a>, a senior <a href="Hamas">Hamas</a> official, said there were promises that the journalists "will not be harmed" and that he expected the situation to resolve in the "coming hours".
Release.
On August 27, the <a href="Palestinian%20territories">Palestinian</a> news service Ramattan and FOX News reported that Centanni and Wiig were released unharmed, shortly after a new video was released. In the video, both journalists, wearing beige robes, read statements saying that they had converted to <a href="Islam">Islam</a>, with Centanni stating "Islam is not just meant for some people; it is the true religion for all people at all times." After being freed, Centanni stated "We were forced to convert to Islam at gunpoint, and don't get me wrong here, I have the highest respect for Islam, and learned a lot of very good things about it, but it was something we felt we had to do, because they had the guns, and we didn't know what the hell was going on."
